required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: AMBULATE Continued Access Protocol to Evaluate the Cardiva Mid-Bore Venous Vascular Closure System (VVCS)
clinical_study.official_title: Multi-center, Single Arm Continued Access Protocol to Evaluate the Mid-Bore Venous VCS for the Management of the Femoral Venotomy After Catheter-based Interventions Via 6-12F Procedural Sheaths With Single or Multiple Access Sites Per Limb

brief_summary.textblock: The objective of the trial is to demonstrate the safety and effectiveness of the Cardiva Mid-Bore Venous Vascular Closure System (VVCS) in sealing femoral venous access sites at the completion of catheter-based procedures performed through 6-12 Fr introducer sheath, while allowing for one or more of the following: elimination of the Foley catheter, elimination of protamine, or allowing same (calendar) day discharge for the appropriate patient population.

detailed_description.textblock: A prospective multi-center, single arm continued access clinical protocol enrolling subjects with multiple femoral venous access sites. All femoral venous access sites will be closed using the Cardiva Mid-Bore VVCS. Subjects will be prospectively evaluated for eligibility in the three study groups in order to answer specific research questions related to safety and effectiveness of the device as it relates to the use of peri-procedural urinary catheters, protamine for reversal of heparin, and same calendar day discharge in a select group of procedure types.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: All subjects will receive the study device for femoral venotomy closure.

primary_outcome.description: Final hemostasis at all venous access sites and freedom from major venous access site closure-related complications through 30 days follow-up

primary_outcome.measure: Major Venous Access Site Closure-related Complications - Safety
primary_outcome.description: Rate of combined majors venous access site closure-related complications attributed directly to the closure method.

secondary_outcome.measure: Study Group Success Rate - No Urinary Catheter Group
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From start of procedure through successful ambulation, assessed to be within 6 hours of final hemostasis
secondary_outcome.description: No peri-procedural urinary catheter insertion required through successful Ambulation (per-patient analyses)

secondary_outcome.measure: Study Group Success Rate - No Protamine Group
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From time of final hemostasis through successful ambulation, assessed to be within 6 hours of final hemostasis
secondary_outcome.description: No delay in Ambulation due to access site bleeding in subjects who receive heparin but are not reversed with protamine (per-patient analyses)

secondary_outcome.measure: Study Group Success Rate - Same Calendar Day Discharge Group
secondary_outcome.description: Discharge within the same calendar day from the start of the procedure without the need for re-hospitalization within 72 hours of hospital discharge due to access site complications (per-patient analyses)

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Evaluated for each access site immediately after device delivery is attempted, reported within 5 minutes of deployment
secondary_outcome.description: The ability to deploy the delivery system, deliver the collagen, and achieve hemostasis with the Mid-Bore VVCS (per-access site analyses)

secondary_outcome.measure: Minor Venous Access Site Closure-related Complications
secondary_outcome.description: Rate of combined majors venous access site closure-related complications attributed directly to the closure method.

arm_group.description: Cardiva Medical Mid-Bore VVCS for venous femoral access site closure

intervention.intervention_name: Cardiva Mid-Bore Venous Vascular Closure Device (VVCS)
intervention.description: The device will be used to close all femoral venous access sites at the end of the case.

provided_document.document_type: Study Protocol, Statistical Analysis Plan, and Informed Consent Form

event.sub_title: Access site closure-related adverse events, excluding major and minor complications
event.description: Access site venous re-bleeding after initial hemostasis confirmed for 5 minutes

event.sub_title: Minor Venous Access Site Closure-Related Complications
event.description: Access site-related hematoma > 6 cm documented by ultrasound

event.sub_title: Minor Venous Access Site Closure-Related Complications
event.description: Pseudoaneurysm requiring thrombin/fibrin adhesive injection or ultrasound-guided compression

event.sub_title: Access site venous re-bleeding after initial hemostasis confirmed for 5 minutes
event.description: Access site venous re-bleeding after initial hemostasis confirmed for 5 minutes

event.sub_title: Access site-related tissue tract oozing – prolonged*
event.description: Access site-related tissue tract oozing – prolonged*

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: The only disclosure restriction on the PI is that the sponsor can review results communications prior to public release and can embargo communications regarding trial results for a period that is more than 60 days but less than or equal to 180 days. The sponsor cannot require changes to the communication and cannot extend the embargo.

point_of_contact.name_or_title: Terry Alverson, Director of Regulatory and Clinical
